issue.title: Rectangle: add support for individual border radius values
issue.body:
``` border-top-left-radius: 10px; border-top-right-radius: 20px; border-bottom-right-radius: 30px; border-bottom-left-radius: 40px; ```
``` border-top-left-radius: 10px; border-bottom-left-radius: 10px; // same as: // border-radius: 10px; // border-top-right-radius: 0px; // border-bottom-right-radius: 0px; ```
testcase.slint ``` import { CheckBox, Slider } from "std-widgets.slint"; component BorderRectangle inherits Rectangle { background: red; border-width: 10px; init => { debug("\{self.border-radius / 1px} <-> [\{self.border-top-left-radius / 1px}, \{self.border-top-right-radius / 1px}, \{self.border-bottom-right-radius / 1px}, \{self.border-bottom-left-radius / 1px}]"); } // tl Text { x: 25px; y: 25px; text: "tl: \{parent.border-top-left-radius / 1px}"; } // tr Text { x: parent.width - self.width - 25px; y: 25px; text: "tr: \{parent.border-top-right-radius / 1px}"; } // br Text { x: parent.width - self.width - 25px; y: parent.height - self.height - 25px; text: "br: \{parent.border-bottom-right-radius / 1px}"; } // bl Text { x: 25px; y: parent.height - self.height - 25px; text: "bl: \{parent.border-bottom-left-radius / 1px}"; } } export component MyWindow inherits Window { width: 800px; height: 500px; property border-color: checkbox.checked ? blue.with-alpha(0.5) : blue; property border-width: slider.value * 1px; ta := TouchArea {} VerticalLayout { padding: 25px; spacing: 25px; GridLayout { padding: 25px; spacing: 25px; Row { none := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; } fifty := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-radius: 50px; } tr-bl := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-top-right-radius: 25px; border-bottom-left-radius: 25px; } tl-br := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-radius: 50px; border-top-left-radius: 25px; border-bottom-right-radius: 25px; } } Row { inc := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-radius: 0px; // unused border-top-left-radius: 10px; border-top-right-radius: 20px; border-bottom-right-radius: 30px; border-bottom-left-radius: 40px; } hundred := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-radius: 100px; } top := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-top-right-radius: 25px; border-top-left-radius: 25px; } bottom := BorderRectangle { border-color: root.border-color; border-width: root.border-width; border-radius: 50px; border-bottom-left-radius: 25px; border-bottom-right-radius: 25px; } } } HorizontalLayout { spacing: 25px; slider := Slider { horizontal-stretch: 10; value: 5; minimum: 0; maximum: 10; } checkbox := CheckBox { text: "Translucent"; } } } } ```
TODO: - [x] femtovg - [x] skia - [x] qt - [x] software - [x] clipping? - [ ] ~~vscode (unknown property)~~ - [x] tests - [ ] optimize bindings Close: #157

comment.body: I changed `RenderBorderRectangle` from a struct to a trait to be able to restore lazy evaluation of `BorderRectangle` properties but I'm not sure what's the best way to pass the `CachedRenderingData` reference with this approach. I made it a separate argument to avoid any ownership issues. The downside is that the argument leaks to all renderers even though it's only needed in the cached partial renderer.

commits.message: Update Translations: extract strings

Document the limitations of the software renderer 

Related discussion: https://github.com/slint-ui/slint/discussions/3782

Co-authored-by: Simon Hausmann <simon.hausmann@slint-ui.com>

wasm: Don't include all image codecs on the lsp

Saves 1M in the binary

We use the browser to render the images anyway

Note: i-slint-core still bring image with png and jpeg codecs, as well
as svg deps. We just need the image-decoders feature to load the builtin
images, of these there are only svg.

janitor: feature cleanup (std is mandatory for the interpreter)

also no need to add default for our internal features, that's counter
productive

node: Fix typescript setup for tests

Share tsconfig.json so that ava runs the typescript compiler also on the tests.
Similary, the syntax check now also covers the tests.

Sadly, the exception that the Slint compiler throws is not type declared,
so we have to use any.
Similarly, the object share returned by loadFile() is unknown
in terms of properties, callbacks, etc.

issue.title: Feature request: callback run on popup close
issue.body:
Related to #3712

In some cases if the `PopupWindow` is closed by clicking outside of the bounds of its content, a callback that runs on this case could be handy for performing certain tasks such as closing or updating other widgets (thinking of "cancel" behaviour).

The callback would be specific to clicking outside of the popup bounds, so that closing via other means does not produce unexpected results.

comment.body:
Suppose we had a `closed-event` callback. My feeling is that if `close-on-click` is true, it should always be invoked - regardless of whether the user clicks inside or outside the bounds of the popup. If `close-on-click` is false, then I think `closed-event` should be invoked when `close()` is called.

@FloVanGH @ogoffart thoughts? :)

issue.title: PopupWindow bounds incorrect if sized and placed

labels.name: a:item tree
labels.description: The runtime data structures related to the items (mO,bT)

issue.body:
The easiest way to demonstrate this issue is to create a window with:

1. A `TouchArea` covering full area and have `clicked` print something
2. Create a popup that is half the window size, and centered with `close-on-click` disabled
3. Click to the left and right

What appears to happen is that clicks outside the positive bounds are passed to the underlying touch area, while clicks in the negative bounds are completely blocked (and also not picked up by the popup).

issue.title: PopupWindow bounds incorrect if sized and placed

labels.name: a:item tree
labels.description: The runtime data structures related to the items (mO,bT)

issue.body:
The easiest way to demonstrate this issue is to create a window with:

1. A `TouchArea` covering full area and have `clicked` print something
2. Create a popup that is half the window size, and centered with `close-on-click` disabled
3. Click to the left and right

What appears to happen is that clicks outside the positive bounds are passed to the underlying touch area, while clicks in the negative bounds are completely blocked (and also not picked up by the popup).

comment.body: Closing since #3776 implements the correct behavior, so that the bounds don't matter (apart from of course reaching TouchArea elements).

wasm: Don't include all image codecs on the lsp

Saves 1M in the binary

We use the browser to render the images anyway

Note: i-slint-core still bring image with png and jpeg codecs, as well
as svg deps. We just need the image-decoders feature to load the builtin
images, of these there are only svg.

janitor: feature cleanup (std is mandatory for the interpreter)

also no need to add default for our internal features, that's counter
productive

node: Fix typescript setup for tests

Share tsconfig.json so that ava runs the typescript compiler also on the tests.
Similary, the syntax check now also covers the tests.

Sadly, the exception that the Slint compiler throws is not type declared,
so we have to use any.
Similarly, the object share returned by loadFile() is unknown
in terms of properties, callbacks, etc.

winit: Clean up event loop state handling part 1

Encapsulate the mouse state in a struct.

winit: Clean up event loop state handling part 1

Move all of the event processing into EventLoopState.

winit: Make it possible to resume the event loop while maintaining state

This way if for example the application quits the event loop while
pressed is true, and then resumes shortly afterwards, we maintain the
pressed state correctly.

Initial implementation of a Slint event loop sitting on top of nodejs

At the moment this is implemented using polling.

cc #2477
